L'ALLEGRO.</br>Hence Melancholy, Care and Sorrow!</br>My heart desires you 'till tomorrow,</br>I have no room within my breast</br>For any dull, cold, lifeless guest.</br>Hence vanish quickly from my sight,</br>And sink to cells of solid night.

But muse!  Thy liveliest numbers bring,</br>For now to joyous Ch—w I sing;</br>Employ thy utmost skill to find</br>Scenes that may suit his jovial mind;</br>For well thou know'st, in fancies gay,</br>He loves to wear dull time away,</br>And smooth the brow of rugged toils,</br>Whilst by his side his Cynthia smiles;</br>And why should sorrows er'e molest,</br>The honest heart or virtuous breast!

Then hither come, life-raising joy,</br>In likeness of a laughing boy;</br>Your head adorn'd with smiling flow'rs</br>The late produce of vernal show'rs.</br>Around thy shoulders let there be</br>A robe of silk, thin, light and free,</br>Part shall thy graceful body bind,</br>And part shall loosely flow behind.</br>Let gentle breezes with thee bring,</br>The choicest odors of the spring;</br>Frolic, frisky, wanton, gay,</br>Round and round thee let them play;</br>Toss thy garments high in air,</br>And wave thy loose, luxuriant hair,</br>Or court the flow'rs that crown thy head</br>Around their opening sweets to spread.</br>And as you thus approach me nigher,</br>Oh!  let me hear the cheerful lyre!</br>Use gracefully the springy quill,</br>And touch it with superior skill;</br>But not to such soft-dying airs,</br>Dissolving sorrows, soothing cares!</br>With which the silly-sighing swain</br>Proclaims imaginary pain.</br>But strike me up sounds brisk and gay,</br>Sounds that shall steal my soul away,</br>Make a soft glow of gladness rise</br>And shew the sparkling in mine eyes.

Thus, thus!  attend me whilst I stray</br>Wild as fancy leads the way;</br>Oe'r high hills by valleys bounded,</br>And o'er plains by woods surrounded;</br>Let me see the world's arch bending,</br>And oe'r the wide seas far extending;</br>Or behold, with wond'ring eye,</br>The rounded globe, the meeting sky:</br>Where the white clouds swimming low</br>Drink the waters as they go;</br>Or where the sun soft dews and rain</br>Exhales, to shed on earth again;</br>Whence skim the dusky shades away</br>Before the splendid god of day;</br>Or where the silver queen of night</br>First gilds the trembling deep with light.

Or let me stray thro' fragrant groves,</br>Where the turtle cooes her loves;</br>Where the linnet's warbling lay</br>Still attends my flow'ry way,</br>And the lark's melodious song</br>Charms me as I go along.</br>Or let me pause and view the scene;</br>The blooming vales, the hillocks green,</br>The stream, that winding in meanders,</br>Thro' the tufted meadow wanders,</br>The fields where flocks forsaken stray,</br>And harmless lambkins sport and play.

But lo! — far off, with roaming eye,</br>Between two oaks a cot I spy,</br>Where Darby sits beside the door;</br>Nor envies kings their boundless store,</br>Whilst Joan, a matron staid and sage,</br>Remains the comfort of his age;</br>And Phillis neat, with voice so sweet,</br>Phillis!  Their hand-maid spruce and neat,</br>Cheers their old hearts with merry song,</br>And spins and sings the whole day long.

And here — beneath a friendly shade,</br>The amorous swain is careless laid;</br>On oaten pipe he loves to play,</br>To wear the tedious hours away.</br>Till Dolly leaves her flock behind</br>Her faithful Thyrsis here to find.

And there behold!  With anxious look,</br>The wily shepherd baits his hook;</br>The fish that late did swiftly glide,</br>And cleft, with glossy fins, the tide,</br>Caught by his art now helpless lie</br>And flutter, pant, and gasp, and die.</br>So — skill'd in love, the cruel swain,</br>Th' unwary maiden's heart to gain,</br>Still ev'ry practis'd treachery tries,</br>Soft languid looks, and broken sighs;</br>Calls heav'n and earth with ardent pray'r</br>His vows of constancy to hear;</br>But when he has the trifle gain'd</br>Soon 'tis neglected, soon disdain'd;</br>Before the false deceiver's eyes</br>It wounded bleeds and throbbing dies.

Thus, let me pass the summer-days</br>In blythsome scenes and jocund ease.</br>But when bleak winter comes amain</br>With all his sullen vap'ry train,</br>And hoary frosts around us sheds,</br>And rattles hail-storms oe'r our heads;</br>Then, when the groves delight no more,</br>Nor songsters warble as before,</br>But ev'ry verdant shelter's lost</br>Nipt by the bitter blasting frost;</br>Soon as the stream, thro' flow'ry ways,</br>No more in murmuring accents strays,</br>But, firmly bound to either side</br>In icy-chains, forgets to glide;</br>Quick let me shun the horrid sight,</br>And to the city take my flight,</br>Where mirth knows one continual round</br>And endless pleasures still abound.

Attend me Joy, attend me there!</br>And let thy presence banish care.</br>Oh!  lead me where the cheerful fire</br>Doth punns, and jests, and wit inspire,</br>And where the slow-revolving night</br>Leaves ample room for long delight.</br>Mean while let Bacchus, jolly boy!</br>Be found thy boon companion, Joy!</br>Let num'rous friends surround the hearth</br>Devoted all the Glee and Mirth;</br>Nor cold nor sorrow dare appear,</br>Nor thought intense nor gloomy fear;</br>But all is airy light and free,</br>And all inspir'd with jollity;</br>While Wit and laughter still doth join,</br>And open hearts are caus'd by wine.

The lawyer — here forgive me Ch—w</br>(Not such a practis'd sage as you)</br>The lawyer lays his wig aside,</br>That wig which did his ignorance hide!</br>That magic wig which charm'd the eyes,</br>And made a very Fool look wise;</br>Which thus pull'd off in merry strain,</br>Displays a very Fool again.</br>The doctor now, skill'd in grimace,</br>No more puts on a double face;</br>Nor does, in oracles, direct</br>Which — life or death — we should expect.</br>The parson here, no longer shy,</br>Lays a formal phyz with cassock by</br>Nor thinks it any crime to join</br>The joys of social mirth and wine.</br>The statesman too forgets his art,</br>And opes to truth his long-shut heart;</br>And, leaving tricks and pride behind,</br>Becomes familiar, true and kind.—</br>Thus Actors, when behind the scenes,</br>Remain no longer kings or queens;</br>Forget the characters they bore,</br>And swear and quarrel as before.

Or while the rigid winter yields</br>Prospects of ice and snowy fields;</br>Soon as the hasty short-liv'd day</br>In the red west withdraws her ray,</br>And glittering stars with radiant light</br>Bedeck the sable garb of night;</br>Quick to the ball-room Joy!  repair,</br>For thou wilt hardly miss me there.</br>Where a promiscuous sparkling throng,</br>The gayly jocund scene prolong;</br>Where art with native beauty joins,</br>And each triumphant fair-one shines</br>In all the pomp in all the shew</br>That dress can give or mirth bestow.</br>Here in full glory may be seen</br>Zaphyra, riv'ling beauty's queen,</br>Around her press the listning throng,</br>To hear the music of her tongue.</br>And whilst in Caelia's robes we find</br>A noble air, a taste refin'd,</br>More pow'rful charms her features wear,</br>For Cupid keeps his revels there.</br>Soft blushes in her cheeks arise</br>And love looks languid in her eyes.</br>Mean while gay wit the time beguiles,</br>And humours quaint, and simp'ring smiles.</br>Dick flaunts it with his tinsel'd coat,</br>And Ned speaks tender lines by rote.</br>Chloe, with blushes, seems to hear</br>Her love-sick Damon sighing near;</br>Whilst Mira both their thoughts descries,</br>And reads soft souls in tell-tale eyes.—

But hark!  the muse's sudden sound</br>Spreads universal gladness round;</br>Joy blooms triumphant in each face,</br>And instant buz fills all the place.</br>And now prepar'd on either hand</br>The beaux and belles in order stand.</br>And now they trip the mazy dance,</br>And to quick movements smoothly glance.</br>Each further partner leads astray</br>Thro' a long labyrinthian way;</br>Each swain pursues his flying fair,</br>Eying her steps with watchful care.</br>Me the thrill-soaring sounds inspire</br>With transports that can rise no higher;</br>My body skims along the floor,</br>I feel my willing feet no more,</br>The music lends me wings, and I,</br>In waving motions seem to fly!</br>And beaux and belles and tapers bright</br>Swim undistinguish'd in my sight!
If such thy pleasures, smiling Joy!</br>Oh may'st thou e'er my mind employ;</br>Dawn in my breast continual day,</br>And chace dull sorrows far away.

IL PENSEROSO.</br>Vanish mirth and vanish joy,</br>Airy pleasures quickly cloy:</br>Hence all ye bacchanalian rout,</br>And quips, and cranks, and gay grimace,</br>And wit that wears a double face,</br>And ev'ry kind of jollity—</br>For you have no delight for me.

But welcome, welcome Melancholy!</br>Thou goddess sage, demure and holy!</br>Exalt thy ever-musing head,</br>And quit, oh quit thy sleepless bed.</br>With languid look, and anxious eyes,</br>Divinest Melancholy rise!

And thou O S—th!  my more than friend,</br>To whom these artless lines I send,</br>Once more thy wonted candor bring,</br>And hear the muse you taught to sing.</br>The muse that strives to win your ear,</br>By themes your soul delights to hear;</br>And loves like you, in sober mood,</br>To meditate of just and good.</br>While Melancholy sooths to rest</br>Each rising tumult of your breast.

Exalted themes!  divinest maid!</br>Sweet Melancholy raise thy head;</br>With languid look, oh quickly come,</br>And lead me to thy Hermit-home!</br>There, let thy sorrow soothing reign</br>Detain me long in pensive strain;</br>Exalt my views and seize me whole;</br>And give me thy delights to know—</br>The heart that bleeds for human woe;</br>The virtuous throb, the grief-swoln eye,</br>The ceaseless tear and deep-drawn sigh.
"Exalted themes!  divinest maid!</br>Sweet Melancholy raise thy head:</br>With languid look, oh quickly come</br>And lead me to thy Hermit-home!"

Or be thou with me whilst I rove</br>Thro' yonder dark untrodden grove;</br>Where the moon is rarely seen,</br>Glimm'ring thro' the dusky green;</br>Whilst a death-like silence reigns</br>O'er hills and vales and distant plains;</br>Nothing but the night-bird's cry,</br>Echoing thro' the vaulted sky;</br>Nothing but the ceaseless rill,</br>Murmuring oe'r its pebbles still;</br>Or the distant falling flood,</br>That shakes the silence of the wood.

There let me wander 'till there's found,</br>Extended on the leafy ground,</br>An oak that many a summer's day</br>Has crumbled in a slow decay.</br>There, stretch'd upon its mossy bed,</br>In listless length, I'll lean my head,</br>While the small worm that grinds its heart</br>Shall music to my soul impart.

Or let me, in some crazy boat,</br>Along the wat'ry surface float;</br>Leaning pensive oe'r its side,</br>To view the ever-rippling tide;</br>Whilst Cynthia's cold declining rays,</br>That now but half her orb displays,</br>On the clear bosom of the deep,</br>In mild composure, seem to sleep.

But hark! — what voice so loud and shrill,</br>From yonder wild romantic hill,</br>Strikes sudden on my startled ear,</br>And warbles forth her ditties clear?</br>'Tis hers — that bird well known to fame,</br>The fond repeater of her name.

Proceed, sweet bird!  I love thy strain,</br>Encreasing still the solemn scene;</br>I'll sit attentive to thy note</br>'Till Cynthia's latest ray goes out.</br>Then, on the margin of the stream,</br>I'll lay me silent, think, and dream;</br>Where no pale glimpse of borrow'd light</br>Breaks thro' the drowsy noon of night;</br>And stars, in vain, with feeble ray,</br>Attempt to give a doubtful day;</br>And clouds far-off, low-low'ring, rise,</br>Possessing first the nether skies;</br>Then, lazy-lab'ring to the pole,</br>Up the steep arch their vengeance roll,</br>Black as the purpose of a guilty soul.

Here, retir'd from noise and folly,</br>Sober-visag'd Melancholy!</br>On a rustling rushy bed,</br>With thee I'll lean the languid head,</br>And in the rolling tide descry</br>The gath'ring horrors of the sky;</br>See the stars dancing as they go,</br>And view the other heav'n below;</br>While, from behind a bullrush near,</br>The frog's hoarse cadenc'd voice I hear;</br>Whose oft repeated hollow sound</br>A pleasing sadness spread around.

But hark! — rude rustling thro' the trees,</br>A sudden unexpected breeze,</br>Swift — rushing from the neigh'bring wood,</br>Shakes the smooth surface of the flood.</br>Now let me raise my downcast eye,</br>To gaze the dark presageful sky,</br>Where clouds, thick gath'ring from afar,</br>Threaten a sudden burst of war.</br>Around an awful silence reigns;</br>Hush'd is each throat thro' hills and plains.</br>The stars, but now, that shone so bright,</br>And twinkled with resplendent light,</br>Slide swift and vanish from my sight.</br>The rapid storm comes on apace;</br>The heav'ns wear one distracted face,</br>The rough'ning blast unbounded roves,</br>In sullen murmurs thro' the groves.</br>Down yonder dreadful depth of sky,</br>In ragged sheets, the lightnings fly,</br>Peals following peals roar thro' the air,</br>And burst in awful ruin near.</br>Descending fast, the heavy floods</br>Dance on the stream and rattle in the woods.

Whilst thus the elements engage,</br>And with redoubled fury rage;</br>Oh let me find some stony shed,</br>Where I may safely lodge my head;</br>T' enjoy the horrors of the storm,</br>And to its God due rites perform.

Beneath yon rock, whose mossy side</br>With awful bend oe'rhangs the tide,</br>Grotesque and wild, a cave I spy,</br>And to its shelter quickly fly.</br>But as I climb the steep, whose height</br>Juts oe'r the flood, a horrid sight!</br>Sent from aloft, with startled ear,</br>A sudden voice of woe I hear—</br>"Rage on thou tempest of the sky!</br>Your fiercest vengeance I defy;</br>A ruder storm whirls in my breast</br>And death alone can give me rest;</br>My sorrows in this stream shall sleep,</br>And I" — then plunges in the deep!</br>Nature awhile, yet fond of life,</br>Maintains with death unequal life,</br>The lover strives to gain the shore</br>But sinks, alas!  to rise no more!
Save me ye gods!  from scenes so sad!</br>Scenes not of Melancholy bred,</br>But sprung from furious wild Despair,</br>In Stygian cell, begot of Care.

But might I hear true love complain,</br>In a more mild and temperate strain,</br>Then let my frequent feet be seen</br>On yonder steep romantic green,</br>Along whose yellow gravelly side,</br>Schuylkill weeps his gentle tide;</br>Rude rough and rugged rocks surrounding,</br>And clash of broken waves resounding;</br>Where waters fall with loud'ning roar</br>Rebellowing down the hilly shore;</br>"And nightly, at the turf-clad grave,</br>In concert with the bird of eve,</br>Beneath the glimpses of the moon,</br>The Hermit mourns Amelia gone;</br>'Till Reason lifts his eye to heav'n</br>And mild submitting tho'ts are giv'n!"</br>Thus Melancholy!  shalt thou please,</br>If thou wilt find me scenes like these,</br>Thus may'st thou e'er my mind employ,</br>And banish ev'ry lighter joy.

But when the summer scenes are lost</br>Welcome winter, welcome frost!</br>Then I'll spend the long long night</br>By the lamp's dim deadly light,</br>Creeping nigher still and nigher</br>To the half-extinguish'd fire;</br>Where, mid glowing coals I view,</br>Lambent flames of livid blue;</br>Or listen to the crackling tread</br>Of heavy foot on snowy bed;</br>While howling blasts around me rage,</br>And wind and snow and hail engage;</br>And thro' a crevice in the wall</br>Boreas whistles shrill and small;</br>And the doors by time grown weak</br>On their iron hinges creak.</br>There I'll muse on stories old,</br>By the toothless matron told;</br>Of a tall, wan, slender Sprite,</br>Stalking in the dead of night,</br>Whose long trailing winding sheet</br>Flows luxuriant round his feet.</br>Fresh gaping wounds all o'er him bleed</br>To disclose some horrid deed,</br>And beck'ning quick he seems to say</br>"Haste to my grave — come, come away!"

Thus should my fancy ever find</br>Some dreadful scene to fill my mind;</br>And thus I'd sit with fixed eye</br>And see the crumbling embers die,</br>Fearing to turn to either side</br>Least there the horrid spectres stride,</br>'Till morn, slow-peeping from on high,</br>Should twinkle with unwelcome eye;</br>Then would I shun th' intruding ray,</br>And hide me from the face of day;</br>Darkling to bed would fearful creep,</br>Hush'd by the roaring winds to sleep.</br>
